title: Are we moving closer to living in Huxley's Brave New World? - Quora

response.answer_text: There certainly many interesting parallels. The entire divisions that currently exist due to wealth and literacy (whether it is technological or simple reading) could easily be transposed onto BNW's Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, or Epsilon types. More than ever, nepotism has stratified certain domains like Hollywood, politics and corporate America. Although most likely not intended, the whole notion of “hypnopaedic” (sleep-teaching) certainly describes what passes for learning in a lot of public schools. The similarity between soma and television needs no explanation. How modern television inappropriately acquaints young children with sexuality mirrors much of BNW as well. Much as with today's sexually liberated youth, one of the book's characters is teased about staying with one partner for an interminable four months. The shock and dismay at seeing visible aged people at the Savage Reservation in New Mexico is already somewhat commonplace with respect to how signs of age are widely regarded as ugly or disfiguring. The popularity of cosmetic plastic surgery, especially in some Asian countries—in many cases having nothing to do with age—are also a manifestation of this overemphasis upon external appearances. The Director's shame over having biologically fathered a son finds comparisons in more recent attempts to portray the nuclear family as an outdated social fixture. While not entirely comparable, the ongoing introduction of artificial insemination, embryo implantation and other in vivo or in utero surgical methods demonstrate a similar divergence from traditional biological reproduction versus the technologically facilitated cloning of BNW. This same unknown biological offspring (i.e., grown child) being brought back from the New Mexican Reservation and becoming somewhat of a celebrity has numerous parallels, be it in the way that New World "savages" like Pocahontas were such objects of curiosity in colonial era England or how aboriginal art forms currently are favored as being more "authentic" or "original" by many modern art critics. Inverted definitions abound such as with the so-called "Hospital for Dying"—as opposed to one dedicated to saving lives—just as Politically Correct speech can often engender similarly awkward malapropisms (e.g., a short person being "vertically challenged"). Liberalism's ongoing fascination with Big Government, especially in the form of One World Government, is given its head and the World State’s policies in BNW are criticized as being dehumanizing, much as persistent concerns about massively centralized government continue to be. BNW's sacrifice of art, science, and religion for the sake of social stability can also be seen in modern day attacks upon free and Constitutionally protected expression in order to avoid hurting the feelings of others. Given the above, yes, we are "moving closer to living in Huxley's Brave New World".

Yes. And a particular aspect of social justice shows how we’re going in that direction. We’ve had forty years of “you should be able to have sex with whoever you want” and “marriage/monogamy is unfairly oppressive”. Now it is turning into “you’re bad if you’re exclusive”. I’ve seen a spate of articles saying you’re bad if you don’t have sex with someone you’re not attracted to. That lesbians are being unfair or bigots if they don’t have sex with biological men in dresses. This is termed ‘the cotton ceiling’. That heterosexual men really should have sex with their homosexual friends, you’re being unfair by not sharing. That a good man lets his wife cheat because it is liberating for her. The rash of articles on how you’re being bad and mean if you don’t have sex with fat people or those you’re otherwise not attracted to, you privileged bully. We’ve gone from “don’t have sex unless in marriage” to “don’t be monogamous, you have to have sex with everyone or you’re hurting them”. In the name of love, fairness and justice, you’re not allowed to say no.

“Just like” is an unwarranted exaggeration. We have no immediate prospects of abolishing natural reproduction in favor of universal in vitro production of embryos, for example. Nor does marriage (or other committed intimate relationships) seem in any danger of disappearing, although it may be changing in some ways.
